I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The 14 Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) are either fragile states or exhibit strong characteristics of fragility.1 Weak economic 
performance  contributes  to  this  fragility,  which  is  linked  to  shortcomings  in  policy  and 
institutional environments as highlighted by ADB’s country performance assessments. For these 
DMCs,  ADB’s  long-term  strategic  framework  2008–2020  (Strategy  2020)  posits,  “due  to 
generally  weak  policy  regimes,  their  often  small  size,  economic  vulnerability,  and  weak 
institutions…ADB must seek innovative means to strengthen the effectiveness of country-led 
models of engagement.”2  
 
2.  As part of the Pacific Studies Series, the expected impacts of the global financial and 
economic crisis and a sensible policy response were presented in an October 2008 policy brief3 
released by ADB. The publication received wide coverage in the region, including at the October 
2008 Pacific Forum Economic Ministers’ Meeting. ADB has subsequently helped coordinate a 
process among the region’s development partners aimed at helping Pacific DMCs respond to 
the global crisis. Consultation has shown there is strong demand for assistance among the 
Pacific DMCs most exposed to the adverse impacts of the global crisis. 
 
3.  This  proposed  regional  cluster  technical  assistance  (TA)  responds  to  these  above 
challenges by adopting innovative approaches to assist economic management in the Pacific. It 
will help Pacific DMCs improve economic monitoring and the formulation and implementation of 
economic policy. Specifically, the first cluster will provide ADB's initial support for a country-led 
response to the global financial and economic crisis. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Long-term growth rates are low in most Pacific economies, and for most of the region's 
population, the long-term process of structural transformation is either absent or has stalled.5 
The  poor  growth  outcomes  can  be  traced  back  to  a  history  of  heavy-handed  economic 
management that manifested in large, inefficient public sectors and excessive barriers to private 
sector  development.  In  the  1990s,  most  Pacific  DMC  governments  adopted  structural 
adjustment programs to open economies and to modernize economic management. These 
programs demonstrated gains from such change, with moderate rates of economic growth when 
improvements were sustained. However, the results from these efforts have remained below 
expectations.  
 
5.  Key constraints lie in the institutional setting, with the prevailing political economy in 
particular  imposing  a  binding  constraint  to  improved  economic  performance.6 This  is  most

evident in the frequent need to repeat externally funded policy analyses and advice, and the

6.  This experience forewarns that a concerted, innovative effort will be required to help 
lessen the impact of the global financial and economic crisis on the region. Lower commodity 
prices have already reduced export incomes, and tourism and remittances are easing as source 
economies  face  tougher  economic  conditions.  The  value  of  most  of  the  region’s  offshore 
investment funds, held by national trust funds and the region’s superannuation schemes, have 
declined substantially.  
 
7.  If a timely and effective response is to be made, extra effort will be needed to improve 
the flow of economic information, to use better economic indicators, and to reduce time lags in 
economic monitoring. Support will also be needed to analyze the impacts of the global crisis on 
the Pacific DMCs and to prepare policy responses. The economic agencies of the Pacific DMCs 
most exposed to the adverse impacts of the global crisis have advised that they would welcome 
help from development partners to strengthen their economic analysis and to respond best to 
the global crisis. 
 
8.  Innovative efforts will be needed to trigger constructive policy and institutional change in 
Pacific DMCs. These efforts need to build on sensitive, long-term relationships between these 
countries and their development partners, and among advisors, reformers, and those impacted 
by reform. Above all, to be successful, assistance for improved economic management needs to 
be tailored to meet individual circumstances and to encourage local ownership and control. 
 
9.  There are some recent examples of the potential economic benefits from policy and 
institutional adaptation. Successes have typically been characterized by local commitment that 
led  to  a  locally  driven  effort.  Consultative  and  participatory  processes,  open  debate,  and 
information sharing assisted the achievement of these helpful changes.7 In addition, successful 
reform in aviation and mobile telecommunications, which allowed new and lower-cost entrants, 
show that alternative approaches to economic management can quickly boost economic growth 
and development. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The proposed TA is to strengthen the capacity of Pacific DMCs to manage for inclusive 
economic  growth—specifically,  to  assist  Pacific  DMCs  in  using  improved  economic 
management processes. This is to be achieved by assistance that offers longer-term benefits by 
helping develop existing Pacific DMC systems and processes for economic management and 
the individual capacity of the region’s economic managers. The proposed TA will help address 
long-standing institutional constraints to change by encouraging demand for better economic 
management. Support is to focus on topical economic issues to capitalize on episodes of 
demand for improved economic management. Innovative modalities will be pursued, including 
the use of a mentoring approach and support for coalitions for change. A cluster TA is proposed 
as a means of progressively raising the intensity of engagement through subprojects linked by a 
consistent approach to achieving change. 
                                                 
7  As  documented  in  ADB’s  recent  Capacity  Development  Series  (www.adb.org/Documents/Studies/  Capacity-
Development-in-the-Pacific/default.asp).

3
11.  Assistance would be provided to Pacific DMCs that demonstrate an appreciation of the 
need to take action to improve economic management. The proposed TA must nevertheless be 
conservative in expectations given the tight limits on capacity, the shortage of experience in 
successful implementation of economic management, and the small amount of funds available 
per country. 
 
12.  Subproject 1 is to focus on a response to the global financial and economic crisis. The 
subproject provides for ADB’s contribution to a joint effort by development partners to help 
Pacific DMCs lessen the effects of the global crisis through improved economic monitoring, 
policy analysis, and dialogue. 
 
13.  The initiation of future subprojects will await the emergence of opportunities to pursue 
demand-driven improvements. Future subprojects will continue efforts to improve economic 
management. Modern, strategic management approaches from other regions, such as support 
for  the  capacity  development  of  coalitions  for  change  or  variants  of  corporate  change 
management, will be applied more intensively with a view to adapting modern approaches to 
Pacific DMC circumstances. Efforts will be made throughout the proposed TA to help civil 
society increase their engagement in economic issues. However, should risk factors eventuate 
and the progress of subproject 1 be inadequate, additional clusters could be brought forward to 
pursue innovative approaches to mobilizing change toward improved economic management 
processes. Such action would be matched by extra efforts to ensure government commitment to 
the TA. 
 
14.  Performance of the proposed TA will be established via demonstrated improvements in 
economic management consistent with international good practices, taking into account regional 
and national circumstances, as assessed through economic reporting.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The planned outputs of the proposed TA are: 
(i)  adoption of an expanded set of economic indicators, including lead indicators 
where feasible; 
(ii)  preparation of economic review assessments; and 
(iii)  high-level  inputs  to  economic  policy  formulation  generated  through  periodic  
in-country and regional high-level dialogues. 
 
16.  Subproject 1, Response to the Global Crisis, will provide for highly experienced mentors 
to guide Pacific DMC decision makers and senior economic advisers. Mentors will apply key 
lessons learned from the Pacific and other regions toward successful economic reform. Coupled 
with the demand for improved economic management that is expected to arise as the global 
crisis expands to the region, the subproject is expected to offer improvements on traditional 
approaches.  
 
17.  The work of the mentors (to be appointed as lead advisers) will be supported by advisers 
and  economic  analysts.  The  provision  of  this  technical  support  recognizes  the  additional 
workload imposed on Pacific DMC economic agencies by the global crisis and the need to fill 
some gaps in expertise. Support will be provided to take full advantage of opportunities for  
on-the-job learning and to transfer needed skills to maximize prospects of sustainability. Where 
support by international consultants is to be provided through repeated visits, progress between 
visits will be used to assess local capacity and ongoing engagement.

4   
18.  In addition to supporting country-level dialogue, subproject 1 will provoke structured and 
targeted regional dialogue that brings together the heads of treasuries and ministries of finance, 
central banks, and market regulators and supervisors. This will help decision makers define 
their own policy position by sharing experiences and debating policy issues, many of which will 
be common across the region. As much as possible, support for regional dialogue will be joined 
to other regional events. 
 
19.  A Pacific economic monitor will be prepared as a compilation of data and economic 
analysis of the impact of the global crisis and proposed policy responses. The monitor is to be 
used to help underpin the analytical content of policy dialogue, and will be widely disseminated 
to raise public awareness of key public policy issues. The economic monitor is to provide a link 
between subproject 1 and the policy agenda of relevant regional economic fora. 
 
20.  Support from subproject 1 will be tailored to the emerging needs of each Pacific DMC. 
The  intention  is  to  supplement  existing  monitoring  to  offer  longer-term  benefits  from  the 
assistance rather than to create a separate, once-off donor activity.8 Country-level assistance 
will be provided in response to a request from Pacific DMCs that spells out the need for support 
and  links  the  request  to  existing  activities,  both  own  and  development  partner-funded. 
Preference will be given to economic agencies that show how staff members will benefit from 
support in an effort to share capacity development support and to lessen the risk that high staff 
turnover will erode sustainability. 
 
21.  The prospects of sustainability will also be enhanced by focusing support on central 
banks  in  close  cooperation  with  other  donors,  including  the  International  Monetary  Fund's 
Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre. Central banks have a direct policy responsibility 
and standing within Pacific DMCs and a demonstrated capacity to raise performance and to 
improve economic management.9 They provide a good basis for developing the coalitions for 
change needed to raise the standard of economic management. Where central banks are not 
present, the focus of support will be on the economic areas of treasuries and ministries of 
finance.  
 
22.  It is anticipated that funds will be used most effectively if operations are concentrated in 
about five Pacific DMCs, complemented by a rapid-response and regional support function that 
can also assist other Pacific DMCs as needs arise. Resource allocations will be responsive to 
the presence of local ownership, prospects for sustainability, the vulnerability of Pacific DMC 
economies  to  the  global  crisis,  and  whether  other  development  partner  activities  (new  or 
existing) can instead accommodate a response to the global crisis. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
23.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $3.5 million equivalent. It is proposed 
that ADB provide $3.0 million equivalent on a grant basis. Pacific DMC governments will finance 
the remaining $0.5 million equivalent. The proposed TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program (TA Special Fund IV). Cost estimates and the financing plan are 
provided in Appendix 2.  
 
                                                 
8  Support is to build on the framework presented in ADB. 2009. Global Crisis Stocktake and Gap Analysis-Enhanced 
Economic Monitoring, Step 1: Indicators. Manila (March). 
9  The improvement in the performance of the Bank of Papua New Guinea since reform efforts in the early 2000s 
being the most recent example.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
24.  ADB’s Pacific Department will be the Executing Agency for the proposed TA as well as 
the  implementing  agency  for  subproject  1.  Funds  for  regional  conferences,  seminars,  and 
training  events  will  be  administered  by  the  Pacific  Department.  Implementation  will  be 
harmonized with the activities of other development partners, principally via the continuation of 
development partner coordination meetings and the establishment of a TA steering committee 
comprising key development partners, the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre, and 
the Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat.10 
 
25.  Consultants will be engaged under subproject 1 on an intermittent basis of 3–9 months. 
Areas of expertise will include economic management and the closely related fields of public 
policy, including economic statistics. A range of experience levels and skills will be engaged to 
allow support to be tailored to the needs of each Pacific DMC. In addition to the team leader, up 
to 5 lead advisers, 5 advisers, and 15 economic analysts will be engaged. Expected results 
include improved economic monitoring frameworks, policy analysis and advice, and the transfer 
of capacity to participating agencies in the Pacific DMCs. An outline of the terms of reference is 
provided in Appendix 3.  
 
26.  Consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). TA consultants will be engaged 
on an individual basis in order to facilitate a rapid and flexible response to the global crisis, the 
topical issues to be explored by follow-on subprojects, and the engagement of specialists in 
economic management who are highly regarded in the region. 
 
27.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook,11 as amended from time to time. The TA is estimated to 
start in June 2009 and be completed in June 2011. 
 
28.  The main outputs will be disseminated widely at regional conferences, at other fora, and 
in the regional press to keep the public informed of key public policy issues and to help mobilize 
public support for improved economic management. The Pacific economic monitor will provide a 
key conduit for communicating economic and policy analysis prepared under the proposed TA. 
Outcome evaluation will be undertaken with the assistance of the steering committee. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
29.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for Pacific Economic Management.

February 2009 at the Pacific Coordination Liaison Office in Sydney, Australia. Attendees were the Australian

Financial Technical Assistance Centre, the World Bank, and (at the 27 February meeting) the United Nations

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Subproject 1: Response to the Global Crisis 
1.  The  first  subproject—Response  to  the  Global  Crisis—of  the  Pacific  Economic 
Management technical assistance (TA) project will support economic monitoring, analysis, and 
policy advice by Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) in a joint effort with development 
partners.  Given  the  recent  emergence  of  the  global  economic  and  financial  crisis,  and 
uncertainty as to its depth and duration, the needs of Pacific DMCs are still being assessed. The 
response of development partners is also in its formative stages; consequently, the following 
resources requirements and terms of reference are indicative only. 
 
2.  A  mix  of  individual  international  and  national  consultants  will  support  Pacific  DMC 
economic agencies in strengthening economic monitoring systems and supplementing these 
systems with indicators tailored to the likely impact of the global crisis on each Pacific DMC. 
This  information  will  be  used  to  provide  higher-quality  advice  to  Pacific  DMCs  and  the 
appropriate response of economic management.  
 
3.  The makeup of assistance will be determined by the impact of the global crisis on each 
Pacific DMC, capacities of each Pacific DMC, the case put forward by each Pacific DMC for 
achieving sustainable impact from the TA (e.g., a group of staff members who will benefit from 
support to minimize the impact of staff turnover), and the availability of national and international 
consultants. The consultants will have a proven ability to review and analyze policy as well as 
form normative policy prescriptions that are consistent with achieving inclusive growth through 
sound institutional arrangements. They will have excellent oral and written skills in English, and 
have publishing experience. Proficiency in the use of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) style 
guidelines will also be beneficial. 
 
4.  The  policy  and  technical  analysis  will  draw  on  relevant  international  and  regional 
literature, data, and analyses, including (i) Pacific DMC national plans and national strategies; (ii) 
the reports and assessments of other development partners; (iii) the Pacific Studies Series, 
including Pacific island economic reports; and (iv) ADB project, sector, and thematic reports. 
Analysis will pay close attention to lessons learned from similar activities undertaken in the past 
to maximize the potential impact and to minimize risk. Efforts will be made to assist Pacific DMC 
economic managers in publicly disseminating key findings from the technical analysis to help 
communities affected by the crisis mitigate adverse impacts and engage in preparation for a 
response. 
 
5.  ADB’s Pacific Department, and specifically desk officers and desk economists in the 
Pacific DMC resident missions, will coordinate the consultant input, including liaising with Pacific 
DMCs, other departments within ADB, and development partners. They will also coordinate with 
individual  country  program  managers  of  other  development  partners  as  appropriate.  The 
country economist (Pacific Operations Division) will have overall responsibility for the subproject. 
 
6.  The work will be undertaken in a phased manner, with research and analyses oriented to 
assisting  informed,  local  participation  in  the  formulation  of  future  phases  of  support.  The 
individual consultants will coordinate their work schedules and engage, to the maximum extent 
feasible, with civil society and staff of Pacific DMC economic agencies including treasuries and

ministries of finance, central banks, planning offices, or units and statistic bureaus in each 
Pacific DMC, as appropriate. 
 
7.  Team  Leader  (international,  9  person-months,  intermittent).  A  team  leader  will  be 
appointed to provide overall intellectual leadership and strategic guidance to Pacific DMCs and 
ADB on the implementation of the subproject. The team leader will also take the lead in 
ensuring lessons from the subproject are transferable to future subprojects of the TA. The work 
is to be cognizant of lessons learned from past experience of Pacific DMC governments and 
development  partners  to  raise  economic  performance.  This  person  will  have  extensive,  
high-level experience (more than 15 years) advising on economic management in Pacific DMCs. 
Duties will include, among others: 
(i)  communicating with assisted Pacific DMCs on the economic impact of the global 
crisis, including country consultation in participating Pacific DMCs; 
(ii)  formulating economic advice on macroeconomic and microeconomic initiatives 
that will lessen the adverse impacts of the global crisis on Pacific DMCs; 
(iii)  providing strategic guidance to Pacific DMC economic agencies on the conduct 
of policy workshops and other public dialogue fora, including at the regional level;  
(iv)  ensuring that quality control processes are in place and implemented through the 
provision of advice to Pacific DMCs by the TA consultants;  
(v)  ensuring that the TA will, to the extent practical, integrate with the analysis, policy 
advice, and institutional and capacity development work of other development 
partners; and 
(iii)  coordinating  with  ADB,  development  partner  staff,  and  consultants  to  avoid 
duplication and to maximize the contribution of development partner resources in 
economic management. 
 
8.  Lead  Advisers  (5  international  advisers,  3–9  person-months  each,  intermittent). 
Working under the overall guidance of the team leader, lead advisers will be appointed to 
provide  a  high-level  mentoring  group  for  economic  policy  makers  in  Pacific  DMCs  on  the 
management of a response to the global crisis. They will be directly supported in their work by a 
regional support team. One of the lead advisers will take a lead role in day-to-day management 
of the subproject, supported as required by a regional support team. Two lead advisers will 
undertake a rapid response role and carry much of the responsibility for coordinating a response 
to  the  global  crisis  with  other  development  partner  initiatives.  The  lead  advisers  will  have 
extensive, high-level experience (more than 15 years) advising on economic management or 
closely related fields of public policy in developing countries, preferably including in Pacific 
DMCs. 
 
9.  Lead advisers will support Pacific DMCs in formulating country-specific proposals to 
improve economic management to respond to the global crisis in a prioritized, sequenced 
manner. The proposals are expected to outline achievable, priority policy options, time frames, 
budget implications including potential funding sources (in broad terms), and the allocation of 
responsibility for implementation. The formulation of policy proposals is to adopt, as a starting 
point, initiatives that are underway and are proving relevant. It is also to build on an identification 
of past success factors and those factors that have detracted from advancing reforms. Duties 
will include, among others: 
(i)  communicating with assisted Pacific DMCs on the economic impact of the global 
crisis, including country consultation in participating Pacific DMCs; 
(ii)  analyzing  lessons  learned  in  the  region  from  comparable,  past  episodes  of 
economic stress, including the 1997 Asian financial crisis;

Appendix 3  11 
(iii)  analyzing the international response to the global crisis and the adaptation of this 
response to Pacific DMCs; 
(iv)  formulating economic advice on macroeconomic and microeconomic initiatives 
that will lessen the adverse impacts of the global crisis on Pacific DMCs; 
(v)  identifying technical support needed by assisted Pacific DMCs to manage the 
impact of the global crisis;  
(vi)  providing strategic guidance to Pacific DMC economic agencies on the conduct 
of policy workshops and other public dialogue fora, including at the regional level;  
(vii)  ensuring that quality control processes are in place and implemented through the 
provision of advice to Pacific DMCs by the TA consultants; and 
(viii)  coordinating  with  ADB,  development  partner  staff,  and  consultants  to  avoid 
duplication and to maximize the contribution of development partner resources in 
the area of economic management. 
 
10.  Advisers  (5  national/international  advisers,  3–9  person-months  each,  intermittent). 
Advisers  will  be  appointed  to  participating  Pacific  DMCs  in  priority  areas  of  economic 
management and to a regional support group. They will have a strong background in economics 
or closely related fields of public policy, such as economic statistics or financial sector regulation, 
including  a  degree  from  an  internationally  reputable  university.  They  will  preferably  have 
experience in Pacific DMCs. The advisers will have a proven ability to review and analyze policy, 
as well as to form policy prescriptions that are consistent with inclusive growth through sound 
institutional arrangements. Working with Pacific DMC economic agencies under the overall 
direction of the lead advisers, the advisers will have a primary role of providing technical support 
and advice to Pacific DMCs, and will for that purpose: 
(i)  prepare economic analyses on the impact of the global crisis on each assisted 
Pacific DMC and key economic management issues to which these impacts give 
rise; 
(ii)  review  and  support  the  improvement  of  systems  and  processes  needed  to 
monitor the impact of the global crisis and to develop a good understanding of 
how adverse impacts can be managed;  
(iii)  formulate economic advice on macroeconomic and microeconomic initiatives that 
will lessen the adverse impacts of the global crisis on each assisted Pacific DMC; 
(iv)  facilitate the conduct of policy workshops and other public dialogue fora;  
(v)  advise on the best means of supporting capacity development in areas with each 
assisted  Pacific  DMC’s  economic  agencies  that  are  critical  to  managing  the 
adverse impact of the global crisis;  
(vi)  ensure that a program of skill sharing and consultation, coordinated within the TA 
subproject  and  with  other  economic  analyses  undertaken  by  ADB  and 
development partners, is implemented both to inform the preparation of advice 
for each assisted Pacific DMC and to transfer, to the extent feasible, the skills 
needed within each assisted Pacific DMC to carry improvements to economic 
monitoring and management to the future; and 
(vii)  coordinate  with  ADB,  development  partner  staff,  and  consultants  to  avoid 
duplication and to maximize the contribution of development partner resources in 
the area of economic management. 
 
11.  Economic Analyst (15 national/international, 3–9 person-months each, intermittent). 
Economic analysts will be appointed to participating Pacific DMCs to support the lead advisers, 
advisers,  or  a  regional  support  group,  or,  in  some  cases,  to  provide  technical  support 
independently. The economic analysts will have a solid background in economics or closely 
related  fields  of  public  policy,  such  as  economic  statistics,  including  a  degree  from  an

12   Appendix 3 
internationally reputable university. Working with Pacific DMC economic agencies under the 
overall direction of the lead adviser or adviser, the economic analyst will have a primary role of 
providing technical economic support to Pacific DMCs, and will for that purpose: 
(i)  assist in research and analysis on the basis of their specialist knowledge of the 
particular technical issue or Pacific DMC economy; 
(ii)  assist with the conduct of economic monitoring and the preparation of economic 
advice to Pacific DMCs on the impact of the global crisis and how they can be 
managed; 
(iii)  support the conduct of policy workshops and other public discussions of policy; 
(iv)  assist  in  the  provision  of  advice  on  the  best  means  of  supporting  capacity 
development in areas critical to managing the adverse impact of the global crisis; 
(v)  ensure that a program of skill sharing and consultation, coordinated within the TA 
and with other economic analyses undertaken by ADB and development partners, 
is implemented both to inform the preparation of advice for Pacific DMCs and to 
transfer, to the extent feasible, the skills needed within Pacific DMCs to carry 
improvements to economic monitoring and management to the future; and 
(vi)  coordinate  with  ADB,  development  partner  staff,  and  consultants  to  avoid 
duplication and to maximize the contribution of development partner resources in 
the area of economic management. 
 
12.  Output/Reporting Requirements. Under the overall guidance of the team leader, the 
lead advisers will be responsible for the quality of all reports, documentation, and submissions 
produced under the subproject to a publishable and high professional standard. All reports are 
to be in English and be suitable for public circulation. With the support of the advisers and 
economic analysts, the lead advisers will submit an inception report, monthly progress reports, a 
draft final report, and a final report to the participating Pacific DMC governments and ADB as 
follows:  
(i)  Inception report. This report will clearly provide a plan for implementation of the 
subproject,  challenges  to  its  success,  and  a  summary  of  the  status  of  TA 
performance. 
(ii)  Progress reports. These brief, monthly reports will inform the government and 
ADB of the status of implementing the terms of reference, plans for achieving the 
TA’s objectives, and a personnel schedule with accomplishments under each 
item  of  the  terms  of  reference.  These  reports  will  adopt  a  uniform  format 
facilitating monitoring 
(iii)  Draft  final  report.  This  report  will  (a)  be  submitted  on  completion  of  the 
subproject, (b) summarize TA activities and recommendations, and (c) provide 
recommendations on any additional steps required on the items of the terms of 
reference. 
(iv)  Final report. This report will be submitted by the consultants within 1 month of 
receipt of the comments on the draft final report from the government and ADB.
